Utterance: Hi! It’s great to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been good, actually. I started that gratitude journal, and it’s been really helpful.
That’s wonderful to hear! What have you been writing about?
I’ve been focusing on the little victories in my music and the good times with my friends. It’s nice to reflect on those moments.
That’s fantastic! How does it feel to write those down?
It feels rewarding. I didn’t realize how much I had to be grateful for until I started writing it down.
That’s a powerful realization. Have you noticed any changes in how you feel about yourself since starting the journal?
I think I’m being kinder to myself. I’m not as harsh when I mess up.
That’s a significant shift! It sounds like you’re making great progress. Have you encountered any challenges while keeping the journal?
Not really. I just sometimes forget to write in it.
That’s understandable. Would it help to set a specific time each week to remind yourself to write?
Yeah, I could set a reminder on my phone.
That’s a great idea! Now, last time we discussed managing feelings of overwhelm. Have you had any opportunities to practice the breathing exercises we talked about?
Yes, I tried it a couple of times when I started feeling anxious about my music.
How did that go for you?
It really helped! I felt a bit calmer and was able to focus better.
That’s excellent! It’s great to see you applying what we’ve discussed. Are there any other techniques you’d like to explore for managing anxiety?
I think I’d like to learn more about mindfulness and maybe some grounding techniques.
Absolutely! Grounding techniques can be very effective. One simple method is the 5-4-3-2-1 technique. Would you like to try it together?
Sure, I’m interested.
Great! Let’s start by identifying five things you can see around you.
Um, I see my guitar, my phone, a plant, a window, and a picture on the wall.
Perfect! Now, what are four things you can touch?
My chair, my guitar, my notebook, and my hair.
Excellent. Now, can you name three things you can hear?
I can hear the clock ticking, some music in the background, and the sound of cars outside.
Good job! Now, can you identify two things you can smell?
I can smell my coffee and a bit of fresh air from the window.
Great! And finally, one thing you can taste?
Just a bit of coffee in my mouth.
Fantastic! How do you feel after going through that exercise?
I feel more present and less anxious. That was really helpful!
I’m glad to hear that! Practicing grounding techniques like this can help you in moments of anxiety. Would you like to incorporate this into your routine?
Yeah, I think I’ll try to use it when I’m feeling overwhelmed, especially before performances.
That sounds like a solid plan. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I guess I’m still struggling a bit with the idea of being a part-time member of the band. I want to feel more secure in my role.
That’s understandable. It’s tough when you don’t feel fully recognized. How has that affected your confidence?
I think it makes me second-guess my abilities sometimes. I worry that I’m not good enough to be a full member.
It’s natural to have those feelings, but remember that your worth is not defined by your role in the band. Have you communicated your feelings to your bandmates?
Not really. I’m not sure how they’d react.
It might be worth exploring that conversation. Open communication can help clarify your position and strengthen your relationships. Would you feel comfortable discussing this with them?
I think I could try. It might help to just get it off my chest.
Absolutely! You deserve to feel secure in your contributions. How about setting a goal to have that conversation before our next session?
Yeah, I’ll aim for that.
Great! I’m looking forward to hearing how it goes. Remember, you’re making progress, and it’s okay to take your time with these feelings.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate your support.
You’re welcome! Take care, and I’ll see you next time.
See you!
